item.title: Keyword Targeting question from Rob in Chicago
item.author: TheVoice@HomeBusinessRadio.net
item.description:
I very much enjoy listening to your show - SEO ADVISOR. I am hoping you can give me some help. I am a sales rep in Chicago for Waste Management and I've decided to create a website to help generate leads.
My website is www.wmchicago.com -
Here is my question (I hope it makes sense).
My keyword phrase is going to mainly target businesses in Chicago. I feel there are a few key phrases I want to target because I feel potential customers can "google" a few different phrases. If they are new customers looking for garbage service, they might type in any of the following:
Waste Management Chicago waste removal Chicago garbage hauler Chicago garbage service Chicago trash hauler Chicago trash service Chicago Waste Management Recycling Chicago Recycling Service Chicago My Home page Title - Description - Content is really focused on the keywords of:
Waste Management Chicago waste removal Chicago -
Here is my question:
- On the home - do I want to key in all the key word searches on my home page: i.e recycling services chicago, garbage hauler chicago, trash hauler chicago, Waste Management Recycling Chicago, Compactors, Green etc.
or do I want to target certain keyword phrases only on particular pages on my website.
EXAMPLE:
Home Page - Use only keywords such as Waste Management Chicago, waste removal chicago -
Recycling Page - Use word only associated with recycling in Chicago - Waste Management Chicago Recycling, Recycling Service Chicago.
Hope that makes sense - I leaning towards using keywords only for the particular page since the CONTENT will be there - i.e. If I make a recycling page and use recycling words - the Search Engines should see the content is about recycling. I think if I use recycling keywords and the content is about compactors - then I would guess the search engines would not give me as high of a ranking.
Thanks for the help - New at SEO - Thanks for all the tips. Rob

item.title: do the search engines treat different domain extensions differently?

item.title: 2 blogs share nearly 100% of the same content
item.author: TheVoice@HomeBusinessRadio.net
item.description:
I have two blogs:
If you look closely, you'll realize that both blogs share nearly 100% of the same content. I did this so that I could further develop the LOCAL blog (since I was trying to get better placement for local potential clients).
Indeed, the LOCAL one took off and is number 1.
The other blog is not doing nearly as well (more competition for the state-wide search term). Though I'm convinced that I'm doing something else wrong that keeps me buried - I KNOW my content is newer and fresher than much of my competition.

item.title: Another question about 'fresh content'.
item.author: TheVoice@HomeBusinessRadio.net
item.description: I am currently developing content for a web site and have a question that hopefully you may be able to answer. You frequently state that adding 'fresh content' to your site is one of the best ways to increase your page rank with the major search engines. Unfortuately most of the pages on my site will contain evergreen content with little need to add fresh content... For example, assume my site was all about furniture refinishing. It might have a page on how to sand drawers, a page on how to repair wood gouges, and a page on how to apply stain. Let us also assume this content is the best written and most comprehensive ever written on the subject. There would be no reason to ever add fresh content to these pages, right? Sure, I could spend lots of time re-writing/re-phrasing/re-structuring copy, but this seems to be to a huge waste of time that adds no value to the user.

item.title: Issue regarding multiple words used in domains, directories, and filenames.
item.author: TheVoice@HomeBusinessRadio.net
item.description:
I have been listening to your podcast(s) for a while and was wondering about a particular issue regarding multiple words used in domains, directories, and filenames.
Here's the question: If you had to rank these choices from best to worst, in terms of good SEO, what would your order be?
Say you had a person's name (or multiple keywords making up a new domain name) that needed to be used in a directory name and also a filename inside that directory.
If the person's name were: Mary Virginia Smith-Collier (as an example), what is your opinion on using the "%20 space character" vs. the hyphen("-") vs. the underscore("_") vs. just running all the names together in one long string, and possibly eliminating a hyphen in a name?
I heard that if the one long string created another "undesirable" word when joined that that would confuse the Search Engine spider and therefore, you should *never* join multiple words as one long string. For instance: Pleasant Hill Estates would give you the obvious: pleasANTHILLestates.com as a sorta funny example.
item.itunes:author: Paul (the voice) Stanton
item.itunes:subtitle: Issue regarding multiple words used in domains, directories, and filenames.
